user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of answer_unique_tiny_response:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
answer_unique_tiny_response (void *cls,
                             struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                             const char *url,
                             const char *method,
                             const char *version,
                             const char *upload_data,
                             size_t *upload_data_size,
                             void **req_cls)
{
  static int marker = 0;
  struct MHD_Response *r;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  (void) cls;  /* Unused */
  (void) url; (void) version; /* Unused */
  (void) upload_data; (void) upload_data_size; /* Unused */

  if (NULL == *req_cls)
  {
    /* The fist call */
    *req_cls = (void *) ▮
    /* Do not send reply yet. No error. */
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */

#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (tiny_body),
                                              tiny_body);
#else  /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (tiny_body),
                                       (void *) tiny_body,
                                       MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
#endif /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection, MHD_HTTP_OK, r);
  MHD_destroy_response (r);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function answer_unique_tiny_response:
#define MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET "GET"
...
#define MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD "HEAD"
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */
explanation:
Only the above if-statement contains calls to functions from <string.h> (strcmp) and therefore is the primary place to verify that pointer parameters reference valid, nul-terminated buffers and are not NULL. Other parts of the function do not invoke <string.h> functions:
- The MHD_create_response_from_buffer[_static] calls and the MHD_* response API use provided buffer/length arguments; they are not string.h calls and so are out of scope for Rule 21.17 here.
- The (void) casts for cls, url, version, upload_data, and upload_data_size are just to suppress unused-parameter warnings and do not use string.h functions.
- The req_cls handling, marker usage, and MHD_queue_response / MHD_destroy_response calls do not call any string.h functions.
Accordingly, only the strcmp usages require investigation for possible out-of-bounds or NULL-pointer issues per MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
